Description
Adadelta
Like RMSprop, Adadelta (Zeiler, 2012) is also another improvement from AdaGrad, focusing on the learning rate component.
AdadeltaConnectionData
 
AdaGrad
Adaptive gradient, or AdaGrad (Duchi et al., 2011), acts on the learning rate component by dividing the learning rate by the square root of v, which is the cumulative sum of current and past squared gradients (i.e.
Adam
Adaptive moment estimation, or Adam (Kingma and Ba, 2014), is simply a combination of momentum and RMSprop.
AdaMax
AdaMax (Kingma and Ba, 2015) is an adaptation of the Adam optimiser by the same authors using infinity norms (hence ‘max’).
AMSGrad
Another variant of Adam is the AMSGrad (Reddi et al., 2018).
BackPropagation
 
BiasNeuron
The bias neuron is a special neuron added to each layer in the neural network, which simply stores the value of 1 and it has no connections

MSGD
Instead of depending only on the current gradient to update the weight, gradient descent with momentum (Polyak, 1964) replaces the current gradient with m (“momentum”), which is an aggregate of gradients.

Printers
 
RandomMutator
In random resetting mutation, we select one or more genes and replace their values with another random value from their given ranges.
RandomSelector
In this strategy we randomly select parents from the existing population.
RandomUtils
Utility library that supplements the standard Random class.
RankSelector
Rank Selection also works with negative fitness values and is mostly used when the individuals in the population have very close fitness values (this happens usually at the end of the run).
Relu
ReLU is the most commonly used activation function in neural networks, especially in CNNs ReLU is linear (identity) for all positive values, and zero for all negative values his means that: It’s cheap to compute as there is no complicated math.

ResilientPropagation
 
RMSprop
Root mean square prop or RMSprop (Hinton et al., 2012) is another adaptive learning rate that tries to improve AdaGrad.
RMSpropConnectionData
 
RouletteSelector
Parents are selected according to their fitness.
RPROP
Rprop stands for 'Resilient backpropagation' and is a local adaptive learning scheme, performing supervised batch learning in multi-layer perceptrons.
RPROPm
No weight back tracking.
RPROPp
The classic RPROP algorithm.
ScrambleMutator
In Scramble Mutation we select a subset of our genes and scramble their value.
SelectionException
 
SGD
Gradient descent is an optimization method for finding the minimum of a function.

A sigmoid function is a type of activation function, and more specifically defined as a squashing function.

SwapMutator
In swap mutation, we select two positions on the chromosome at random, and interchange the values.

TournamentSelector
In K-Way tournament selection, we select K individuals from the population at random and select the best out of these to become a parent.
TrainingData
This class holds the input data set and a target data set used to train a neural network

TwoPointCrossover<C extends Chromosome<?>>
Is a generalization of the one-point crossover wherein alternating segments are swapped to get new off-springs.
UniformCrossover<C extends Chromosome<?>>
In a uniform crossover, we don’t divide the chromosome into segments, rather we treat each gene separately.
